column4: Hi. I just installed Ubuntu Desktop 10.10.  I rebooted my machine and now I have  grub> sitting on my screen. Not sure what to do.
Do you have more than one hard drive?
I am using a Dell Perc 6i PCI card to manage a RAID5 array of5 disks 4TB
Does "ls -l" at the grub shell seem to list the array as a single drive, and correctly display its contents?
Interesting. It doesn't list any filesystems that it *can* understand?
Never mind, misread.
Just the hd0,gpt2: ext2
So it can read the swap partition..i guess
If you "ls (hd0,gpt2)/" do you see what looks like the files of a root filesystem? (/var, /etc...)
Yes
What happens when you run "configfile (hd0,gpt2)/boot/grub/grub.cfg"?
My screen was cleared, grub> _ is now at the top of the screen
Any errors if you run "source (hd0,gpt2)/boot/grub/grub.cfg"?
none
Do you see kernel images if you "ls /boot/"?
nothing happened, no error, no confirmation, no msg
I see system map, abi, memtest86+, vmcoreinfo, vmlinuz, nothing about Kernel
The files like "vmlinuz-2.6.32-25-generic" are the kernel images.
Oh, okay
Are you familiar with tab completion?
I'm experienced with computer hardware, electronics, and windows but I don't know anything about Linux

In a bash shell you can type the first few characters of a filename then hit the tab key to automatically complete the rest of it. The same is true for the grub shell, and for your IRC client with nicknames (try typing "Jord<TAB>").
...oh god that helps
neat

To boot manually from the grub shell run "linux /boot/vmlinuz-2.6.32-25-generic root=/dev/sda2" (use tab completion for vmlinuz...) then "initrd /boot/initrd.img-2.6.31-20-generic" then simply run "boot".
By the way, as a first experience with Linux you've been thrown into the deep end. This is far from normal :)

I've been trying to setup a f-ing ESXi 4.1 server for 2 weeks straight, said screw it and tried to run ubuntu and consolidate Win Home Server into Ubuntu for my media purposes.  I've been trying to get Ubuntu to install correctly/not corrupted/not bugged for 3 days now
Btw, file not found on the linux command

Did you use tab completion? The filename I gave was just a quick example from my system, it won't work on yours. Use "linux /boot/vmlin<TAB> root=/dev/sda2" then "initrd /boot/initrd<TAB>" then "boot".
Ah, okay.
i appreciate your help
invalid magic number
That means that the file wasn't actually a linux kernel. Let me recheck my instructions.
Maybe I should just start there,again? lol

Have you ever seen the error "out of disk"? It's a symptom of a BIOS bug that won't cause problems untill you need to read files far into a large drive (so it can pop up unexpectedly on a previously working system).
No, I haven't.
I know if I use my nForce 680i fakeRAID i can overflow my bios' raid size (limit of 2 TB), but Ubuntu reads it, until it restarts. xD -- But this time I'm usingthe hardware raid from Dell
You're familiar with the difference between FakeRAID and true hardware RAID, and you're currently using true hardware RAID?
Yes, the Dell PERC 6i PCI-e 4x ($300 retail) card sitting in my computer is hardware raid.
If It isn't heads will role
and it isn't hardware assisted raid either.
or shouldn't be

Then I'm really curious why you're having problems. The file that you tried to load was not a valid linux kernel, but it should have been. It may be that the file got corrupted at some point. Did you run the integrity test on the Ubuntu install CD?
Us windows users never run that stuff. ..i mean, no. I think? I don't remember.
Normally I don't, but I do remember doing it for one of this newly burned disks, perhaps it was the server CD i verified?
Try booting from the install CD and running the check. If it fails then you have your answer.
The Driver BIOS did its startup check, everything looks fine.  Booting to Ubuntu LIVE
Do I install ubuntu or Try Ubuntu? Where is the disk verify option?
You have to press any key during the first five seconds of boot to see the menu (The boot menu is displayed by default on the server install CD which is what I thought you had used).
I have both CDs here...
Run the check on the one you installed from.
checking disk now
No errors found
Ok. Can you boot from the LiveCD, run boot info script as explained here: http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=1291280 and pastebin the RESULTS.txt it produces?
will do
http://dl.dropbox.com/u/6629357/RESULTS.txt
You should definitely be seeing a menu at boot.
well, lets see what happens *rebooting*
Okay, I booted into Grub, again, however there is NOT an error.
it says "gnu grub version 1.98..........ubuntu4,and then a paragraph of bash-like editing is suported. Again, no actual error
If you run "cat /boot/grub/grub.cfg" from the grub shell does it appear to be a normal text file (no unprintable garbage that would suggest corruption)?
:| out of disk
so what does that mean again? shoot myself? ....
That explains everything. You do indeed have a buggy BIOS, and it's easy to work around :)
Which BIOS? Dell PERC bios or motherboard BIOS?
Motherboard.
you know, for $50 a pop I could go buy some DELL PowerEdge 2850 servres off of ebay and fix all my fing problems. ...
would you like to guess the name brand of the MB? ill give you a hint, their support is 0.
You can work around the problem by creating a small /boot/ partition near the beginning of the drive. That way everything that needs to be read through the BIOS is within your BIOSs limits.
I received other errors in ESXi, perhaps this will explain it.
oh, that doesn't sound tooo bad.
Do you have a link to a walkthrough or how am I to do this?
Looking for a good guide now.
Thanks :)

I can't find a good guide, and it would take me a few hours to download the server iso. So I'll try to walk you through installing with a separate /boot (it's not too hard) but you'll have to describe or upload pictures of what you see.
okay
I have a web cam ..lol
Go through the install up untill partitioning, choose manual partitioning then upload a picture (or try to figure it out yourself, you probably can).
Running setup now.
I'm at the partitioner
I want to make a Boot (100megs), Root (4TB), and swap (6GB), so 3 partitions? (im guessing here)
I just finished downloading the minimal install iso which uses the same installer as the server iso. I'll have step by step screenshots in a few minutes.
So I should use the Server Install disk then?
Yes.
rebooting

an entire GB to my 'boot' area, such a waste of my 4 TBs xD
1 GB is not required, but as you say it's not much when you have 4 TB :)

thanks a billion.  hopefully I'll get this to work smoothly.
